text: what does butter tell you about the
European Union it's a simple pleasure
but it became more expensive when we
joined what was then the European
Economic Community back then we imported
loads of cheap butter from New Zealand
but that had to change when we signed up
to Brussels and it had to change because
of these three letters they stand for
the Common Agricultural Policy and it
was set up to both make Europe
self-sufficient in food and to support
European farmers which is why we had to
buy more of our butter from Europe and
not New Zealand
now the c.a.p supports farmers by paying
them subsidies in 2014 the British
farmers received about two and a half
billion pounds in these subsidies and
without it many of them would have gone
bust but each year as part of our
contributions to the EU Britain pays
about twice that amount to the c.a.p to
support farmers in other parts of Europe
now to get the payments farmers have to
meet environmental food safety animal
welfare and traceability standards
critics of all this say that the c.a.p
uses up far too much money it accounts
for about 40% of total EU spending now
that's something to chew on
and nothing is better than butter for
keeping the old man
